I have a theory about why men lose hair on the top and front of the head only. The theory is as follows:
The hairs on the side and back of the head are subjected to high pressures during the night when we sleep for about 8 hrs during and entire life. The pressure is caused when you lean your head on the pillow, this pressure sends the hairs deeper inside the follicles and roots them more firmly in place. You often roll on the pillow left and right during the whole night creating pressure around the head, however, on the top and front of the head you NEVER put pressure; for that reason I hypnotize that the lack of pressure on top of the head is the cause of hair loss. If we did not spend 8 hrs leaning our back and sides of the head for an entire life, we would lose the same amount of hairs as we lose on the top.

DHT sticks to hair and miniaturizes it. Healthy individuals have enough SHBG to bind with testosterone and DHT to prevent their hairline from receding, but people with low SHBG don't have enough of the globulin to bind with the testosterone floating in their body. It's been found that below-normal values of SHBG are reported in people suffering from MPB; did you know low SHBG is associated with high levels of insulin? Your body releases a growth hormone called, insulin growth factor 1, during puberty because it is vital for your development, but the biological mechanism behind this release is insulin. You only release insulin when your body needs to break down sugars and when you release insulin your liver also release IGF-1. With that said, if you are experiencing some form of hair loss chances are you are developing an insulin resistance, or at risk of developing one. If you are experiencing a degree of recession that would be considered not typical, you should definitely get your hormones check because hair loss is a visual indication of an underlying problem.

Embryos can't develop without X chromosome. The X chromosome contains about a thousand genes, that's about 4% of the genome.

In most primates and other animals, the hemispheres of the brain divide the processing of tasks somewhat equally. But in humans, the hemispheres tend to specialize: Nearly all righties process language in the left side of the brain, while many lefties process language on the right. Pattern baldness is essentially an energy problem, which leads to a series of unfavorable changes in the body, namely, the dysregulation of the adaptive “anti-hair” stress hormones: serotonin, estrogen, prolactin, adrenaline, cortisol, aldosterone and parathyroid hormone. Supporting robust thyroid status will stop (or reverse) it.
